Another counter-argument to Pascal's Wager: "The concepts of Heaven and Hell, are a part of religion itself, so they're subject to question too. So, doesn't that make the supposed reward/punishment of belief/disbelief kind of meaningless?"

The Wager describes a way of behaving rationally, given significant uncertainty about the outcome of one's actions and accepting the premise that neither belief nor unbelief would be irrational; it does not and is not meant to describe a way of producing rational beliefs. The Wager, properly understood, is not proposing that the questioner abandon the question of Christianity and blindly accept the claim of Christianity. It is closer to proposing an experiment: "Live life as a Christian," Pascal seems to be saying, "and see if you still feel that you are giving up so much by doing so, and see if your doubts recede or return.

Pascal thought he was being pragmatic, but failed to realize two important flaws: 1-What if you believe in the wrong god? With all the sectarian options, Pascal chose only the Catholic god (no small wonder as France was intensely catholic at the time). 2-Belief in any god does come at a price. Another mathematician, Pierre LaPlace when asked why  his model of the Universe hadn't included God said, "I had no need of that hypothesis." From this we can realize that if we have the choice of making up a solution with no evidence of its truth, we should leave that part out lest it interfere with the facts for which we DO have evidence. Pascal, it turns out, wasn't pragmatic, except in that his culture might well have killed him as a heretic for a failure to believe in the catholic god. Not very pragmatic of french culture to kill off an otherwise brilliant mind.

This video is actually wrong about Pascal's wager. It doesn't depend on belief not costing anything. The actual argument is that the cost of belief is finite and the consequences of belief or disbelief are infinite (i.e. heaven and hell). Any finite cost is outweighed by an infinite benefit no matter how small the odds of gaining that benefit.

I'm an atheist. Having said that, here's what I think (my opinion, yours might differ),  “Pascal’s wager” is a classic example of a choice under uncertainty. The uncertainty is whether God exists. Belief or non-belief in God is the choice to be made. Pascal argues that the reward for belief in God if God actually does exist is infinite, while the cost of believing in God if God actually does not exist is low. Therefore, the expected value of belief exceeds that of non-belief, so Pascal contends that it is prudent to believe in God. People tend to forget the rationale with pascals argument and his viewpoint, he arguing simply based on the theory of "Expected Value" (that is something has +ve expected value if the benefits  outweigh the costs, which indeed do as per his argument), he clearly didn't want any non believers to believe or had any religious disbeliefs whatsoever. Drawing conclusions without knowing the person's rationales and assumptions is a fatal mistake.

I find Pascal's focus on increasing the numbers of followers over doing the much more difficult work of changing their internal emotional climates to make them better "Christians" to be crass and cynical.  In effect Pascal just wanted more followers for his particular version of a monotheistic god, not to produce truly effective and personally beneficial changes in the follower's thought processes.  Following ritual by rote is hardly likely to change anyone in a positive way.

I set for myself this belief:

- A god only interested in me worshipping him rather than what I do for others (words/ beliefs vs. actions) is no god worth believing in.
- As a consequence it's irrelevant for me if god (which one ever) exists or not. As long as I do the right/ moral thing (largely directed by utilitarianism)
- If god is omni-benevolent AND omniscient he should recognize that people, only believing in him for the sake of doing it (getting something out of it for themselves) are people with bad faith. You should be convinced of the cause and rationally/ logically decide for it to be the best.
- Otherwise (as I mentioned already) he is not worth following and I can live with myself going to hell/ getting punished for not believing in him when I die (should he exist)
- It just contradicts itself for me to have a god, who rather judges you for what you worship than what you actually did in your life.
So an atheist nurse or doctor for me had a better/ more moral life than a religious trader.

The Lost Ark is a better Indiana Jones movie for this point.  When the Ark is opened, Jones tells his companion to close her eyes and not open them no matter what.  There’s no “magic” evidenced at this point...just his knowledge of what is reputed to happen to those who gaze upon the ark when it’s opened.  While the end of the movie doesn’t establish Jones as a “believer,” he does seem aware that the Ark is real...even if he doesn’t understand exactly what it is.  In later movies, Jones is just replaying the same basic plot...so, arguably, he’s more of a believer in these things because he’s discovered there is something behind them.

Unlike the teapot, faith in God is not some ultimately unknowable conjecture. As with the invisible bridge, a leap of faith is required, but when you find yourself miraculously supported over the chasm, your faith is rewarded. This encourages the believer, and they take another step in faith, to find it too is rewarded. Thus their faith grows, and they start to walk more confidently with each step. It is no longer blind faith, but faith in something we have direct experience of.
In Romans 8:16 there is a promise. "The spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit." His spirit will witness with ours, confirming that He does indeed exist. This is a direct experience of God's existence. Deeper than any empirical evidence. Deeper than the witness of your best friend telling you something that's true, and you know it's true because you know your friend so well you can tell just from their face. (After all, who would accept ANY empirical evidence, or even the word of their friend? Wouldn't we need to experience this ourself before we were convinced?)
The instructions for how to receive this witness from God are many, and tend to differ for each of us, but are best summed up in Hebrews 11:6: "He that cometh to God must believe that he is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently seek him." We must each approach Him ourselves, sincerely, and in faith and humility. We need to walk out onto that invisible bridge for ourselves. We can never empirically prove it to others, or even convince others who know us to be honest, but we can directly experience it for ourselves, and that changes everything. A walk of faith begins, which is a relationship with God, on His terms.
All religion is evil. The opposite of faith, with blind ritual observances controlled by hierarchies of priests, requiring blind faith in THEIR words. True faith is a moment to moment walk in a deep and growing personal relationship, with no intermediary between ourselves and God except Jesus Christ Himself, who's witness and testimony stands, and can be confirmed by anyone who truly follows His instructions.

I'm sorry, but this is really not a good representation of Pascal's wager. Pascals wager is not about, and has never been about, simply forcing yourself to believe because it's practical. Pascal argues that, when searching for God and truth, if the evidence seems to be equal between atheism and Christian theism, that one should choose theism over atheism.

Yes, this wager can technically be applied to any theistic system, but this is no argument in favor of atheism. It could really be argued that any theistic system is metaphysically more beneficial than atheism. Furthermore, one must then weigh the evidence of the options between different theistic systems to determine what one should follow.

Pascal's Wager is extremely inaccurate because it assumes that there's only one god that you can believe in. In fact, is estimated that there are between 8,000 to 12,000 gods, so the real benefit of believing in a god is not much more than not believing. Think about it this way, if we averaged the number of gods to 10,000 (some of them come in a package), then you only truly have a 1/10,000 chance (or 0.001%) of receiving any real benefit. If Pascal's Wager is your justification, beware that your chances of receiving a real benefit are almost null.

From Pascal's Pensee
"Wager: You can either believe that God is, or He is not. See it as a wager. If you gain, you gain it all; if you lose, you lose nothing. Wager, then, without hesitation that He is. - "That's very fine. Yes, I must wager; but I may perhaps wager too much." - Let is see. Since there is an equal risk of gain and of loss, if you had only to gain two lives, instead of one, you might still wager. But there is an eternity of life and happiness.

Now, what harm will befall you in taking this side? You will be faithful, honest, humble, grateful, generous, a sincere friend, truthful. Certainly you will not have those poisonous pleasures, glory and luxury; but will you not have others? I will tell you that you will thereby gain in this life, and that, at each step you take on this road, you will see so great certainty of gain, so much nothingness in what you risk, that you will at last recognise that you have wagered for something certain and infinite, for which you have given nothing."

I don't think this video 'gets' Pascal at all - thinking he was much more of a fideist and irrationalist than he actually was. He believed that God had created enough reason to believe to make faith rational, but had also created the world so there was always the potential of unbelief. The reasons helped, but they don't prove. There is always room for doubt. God wants the world to be this way to faith is always a choice and not compelled by reasons alone. He wrote, "we arrive at truth not by reason only but by the heart." Notice: he said, "not by reason only." God has provided reasons to believe but these are not sufficient. We need more than reasons; we need the heart to believe. He's not an irrationalist but a person who is skeptical of the value of apologetics alone to motivate faith. God wants to protect the right and the privilege to disbelieve by creating a world with room for doubt. Atheists will always have their reasons but the reasons for faith are real They don't get you all the way there. Thus, the wager.

Many comments point out that another possible objection to Pascal's Wager is that we still don't know what God to believe. There are dozens of religions, and believing in any 1 false religion can still land you in hell. Let me play Devil's Advocate (or is it God's advocate?) and try to refute this objection.

Imagine if, in the decision matrix in the video, instead of 2 columns ("God exists" and "God doesn't"), there are 3 ("The Christian God exists", "The Islamic God exists" and "No God exists") (there can be more religions obviously, I'm just using these as examples).

As a betting man, it's still better for me to bet on 1 of the religions (Christianity or Islam) than it is to bet on atheism. Why?
If I choose a religion and it's wrong, I get the same punishment as the atheist (hell).
However, if I choose a religion and I'm right, I get a reward the atheist doesn't (heaven).
So betting on a religion is no worse than betting on atheism (and at least I might win something).

So then which religion do I choose, Islam or Christianity? Well, I can compare the Bible and the Quran and weigh the arguments for both religions and decide which seems more plausible to me. However, the point I wanted to make is that EITHER of those choices would still be better (or at least, no worse) than atheism.

Virtually all of the problems associated with the wager can be solved by putting it in the context I defended below. For instance, Russell's teapot religion which is simply based on the observation that the teapot cannot be disproven so faith in it is rational. That bears no similarity with Pascal's project. He believes there are actually tons of good reasons for faith. That is why he wrote the Pensees! It is a work of natural theology for heaven's sake. He's seriously trying to convince his atheist friends to become believers on the basis of countless Pensees or thoughts. It isn't as if he's simply saying, "Belief in God may be irrational but it cannot be disproven and it has wonderful benefits!" He was saying something much more profound and subtle. But these distinctions are lost here. You cannot simply say, "If you can leap to belief in God, you could just as well jump to belief in a flying teapot." That is no critique at all. Pascal had provided all kinds of evidences for faith. Again, that is what the Pensees is - a book of reasons for faith, reasons to believe faith is rational and warranted as constituting true knowledge. The Wager is only meant to be a final nudge for those hanging on the fence.

I heard a Pascal scholar (Tom Morris at Notre Dame at the time) say that the wager has to be understood in the broader context of the Pensees in which reason has a very important role in faith. Hank doesn't seem to get this. Pascal was not an irrationalist or fideist. He certainly didn't believe faith was simply a useful fiction! He believed in God for reasons. Read the Pensees - it is full of reasons. He was trying to convince his atheist friends using natural theology and other arguments. The Wager was not an admission that there are no reasons! It was meant as a final push for those who might still remain on the fence even after considering all the other reasons Pascal had been providing. The wager was a response to someone who said something like, "I see all your evidence for God, Pascal, but you're expecting me to commit myself 100% and I don't feel like I have 100% confidence. So I remain undecided." Then and only then, he introduces the wager. Thus, the wager is broadly misunderstood and its real brilliance lost.

I feel like there is a more pragmatic religious reason to Kierkegaard's argument for Fideism, and that being that it is clearly based on the Protestant (or at least Martin Luther inspired ones) notion of Sola Fide, or "Faith Alone". Unlike Catholics who believed that you needed to perform certain actions, observe certain rules, and a bunch of other things, Protestants believed that the only thing you need to go to heaven is belief.

So Kierkegaard (who being Danish was probably raised Protestant), had a religious motivation to argue against the argument and evidence based methods of faith that were found within the Catholic Church, and focus more on the raw spiritual power of belief that we see in Sola Fide focused Protestantism.

So while Fideism works within a Sola Fide concept of God and the afterlife, it falls flat against a theological world view that looks to evidence of God's will within the natural world and order of the Universe.

This is why I dislike Pascal's Wager:

If one is agnostic (like myself) then they are acknowledging that they do not know about God. Any God is on the table. By taking Pascal's Wager, one assumes that believing in God is what God wants. But without any information about a possible God, we don't know what it wants. It is equally likely that genocide gets one into heaven and that faith gets one into heaven.

Another risk unmentioned is starting the trend of believing untrue things.  A nonexistent afterlife can also make one take their presumably one and only, finite life less seriously and not live their life up to maximum fulfillment.  Thereby losing quality of life (sex-negative cultures, freedoms), possibly length of life (vaccines, blood donations), and quite possibly increase suffering (aforementioned, guilt).  Then it's just over with no way to nake it back up.

Blaise Pascal lived in the mid 17th century, after the King James Bible, after the Church of England, after Martin Luther's reformation. Each church separately decreed Extra Ecclesiam nulla salus (In English: No salvation outside [our] church ). So even in Pascal's time, not including the Jews and Muslims (who have their own schisms) Pascal totally did his math wrong. It wasn't betting red or black, but on one of several numbers.

Today, there are forty thousand separate denominations of Christianity, most of which are still stingy about sharing heaven. Though, granted, many offer salvation to some similar denominations, to all denominations or even to everyone. The last bull on the issue passed by the Holy See was by Benedict (the scary Palpatine pope who resigned) who said the Eastern orthodox churches are in, but protestants are out and damned to eternal hellfire, the lot of them. Pope Francis has said much about including others, but hasn't actually changed Vatican policy.

What I find noteworthy about this is the other math: When we count all humans who lived, and we assume that current policy stands (also, being generous that no Catholic or Orthodox is turned away due to their own sins), then Hell is occupied by 100 billion people compared to (generously) two billion in Heaven. If someone's keeping score (or as some lore goes, they're both building armies to fight each other) Hell is winning by a long shot. Considering the atrocity that is eternal torture in Hell, would it not be the greatest ecclesiastic act ever to the Pope if he would retroactively offer salvation to everyone, living or dead?

If the Pope believes the dogma, it's a no-brainer. Of course, it'll have unpredictable effects on the political integrity of the church, so if the Pope has any doubt, he might hold off.

But another reason for believing things without evidence, or even things with abundant evidence to the contrary is that they had these beliefs implanted at a time when their trust outweighed their curiosity or their doubfulness, eg. a person following this or that religion of lifestyle since they were children, because they just did what their parents told them to because when they were children they had an inflated view of the reliability of their parent's word. And once they mature and become more discerning and less automatically trusting, they may not think to apply their new reasoning skills to those beliefs which they already had built in by the time their more logical mind 'switched on'.
I suppose this is why some object to forcing certain beliefs or attitudes onto children, and see it as indoctrination, because while somebody is a child, their can be convinced of all sorts of things that may go on believing into their adult life, when if they had been given the chance to mature and aquire a discerning, reasoning mind they would have surely dismissed. Pascal's Wager doesn't really make sense. There are literally thousands of deities and so believing in just one, simply because it COULD be true, because you don't want to risk an eternity in hell would only make since if that was the only faith where a "non believer" would suffer such a fate. But what happens if you choose to believe in God (the Christian one) and he not only doesn't exist but a different God (or goddess or multiple gods and goddess) does exist and that God sentences you to an eternity of hell (or something similar to it) because you didn't believe in him?

So the idea that you should believe in the Christian god because it is the "safest" option just isn't true because one could argue this about other religions as well.

The key weakness of Pascal's argument is that he's assuming that there are only two religious views: the orthodox Christian position and atheism. That's not true, of course; there are many different religious ideas in the world and plenty of them are mutually exclusive. Fundamentalist Muslims, for instance, believe that only Muslims can go to heaven, and Christians are making a bet that they're wrong about that. Sorry, but there's no way to avoid rolling the dice on eternity.

Pascal made an assumption that makes his calculation wrong. He assumed that even though we can't know that God exists, we can still know that the church understands God's rules and expectations. It is the church that says we will suffer all the torments of hell if we don't believe in God. Since we have no way of knowing if God exists, we also have no way of knowing if God will punish us for denying him. In fact, we have no way of knowing if hell even exists (even theists are divided on this subject). So it is very likely that there is no downside to not believing in God.

As much as I love crash course, Pascal was not necessarily arguing for God, he was arguing against atheism. The wager is a sledgehammer against unbelief. (Just read the rest of his book). And secondly, the fact that one cannot prove God, does not mean that one cannot have evidence for faith. (You can't prove your reason aligns with reality either, but it's plausible most of the time). So he was advocating blind faith, but reasoned faith. Faith, for Pascal, was the most plausible decision (more rational and plausible than atheism) and the Wager was designed to rattle his unbelieving friends out of their complacency. So on this one Hank, ...er, not quite so. (But I still love your stuff)

One interesting parallel about Pragmatism and evolutionary epistemology. If natural selection favors the beliefs with functional survival benefits, thats much like pragmatism: just because belief produces a favored function does not make the belief true. Alvin Plantinga said it as follows, suppose you believed tigers are furry fun play things in and the method of play involves hiding or running from them. Those actions would increase survival despite the belief being false that tigers ought to be played with.

Hank ignored the reality that any belief requires faith: epistemically, you can't, beyond a shadow of the doubt, know anything. You must make assumptions about reality to even try to begin to understand anything. In that sense alone ought faith be seen as blind (even though some assumptions are core and must be blindly held, it does not remove the reality that they can be reasonable). Empiricism leads to an intrinsic contradiction and does not resolve the issue (there is no way to physically prove that we need to prove everything physically). When you define "faith" as blind its easy to knock down, but that is nothing more than a straw man: faith need not be blind! Justification can go beyond the physical and lead you to rational warrant (see Plantinga's "Warranted Christian Belief").

Main problem is confusing credulity, or, mere belief, with actual faith. Real faith requires evidence and involves the brain. (And yes, I know the English word is used to mean both things, as well as other definitions; unfortunately this can lead to lack of clarity.)
As an illustration: you may believe that daddy is bringing home a pony. Without evidence, though, all you have is wishes and belief, however unfounded. Now, if your daddy TOLD you he's bringing home a pony, AND he has never lied or fooled or tricked you, you have some basis for your belief. Or, perhaps he has built a stall, bought some hay, watering buckets, horse blankets and lead lines. Now you can say you have evidence for your belief; it is faith. You may not see the pony yet (that would be proof), but you have something to reason on to draw a logical conclusion about the unseen.
For something to really be faith, and not just mislabeled belief, you have to have some evidence to reason on.

I think the belief in "God" or not in "god" boils down to the fundamental question... is the universe fundamentally deterministic or is it ultimately random? If its deterministic than everything happens due to causality. An example is how do you predict the weather perfectly? You can develop theory based on our understanding of pressure ect, and have instruments that measure temperature to build a model with practical usefullness. However the curve of accuracy decreases exponentially the father out into time you go. In order to predict the weather perfectly you would have to take everything into consideration, from how the sun effects our weather, to other stars effect on our sun, to galaxies effect out to infinity. The only way to predict the weather perfectly (or anything) is to know everything perfectly. I call this view of knowing everything perfectly as "a God's eye view". When anything happens its in accordance with "God's will" or causality. The opposite view to this is the universe is ultimately random (ie there is no ultimate rules that dictate how the universe has to work). Randomness is a difficult thing to quantify, in maths there is no such thing (discovered anyways)as "true or absolute" randomness. When you try to program a random number generator what your really doing is making something that is so complex its effectually random. The bottom line is (in my view anyways) that we are doomed to the approximate due to our limited perspective. The universe is effectually random in that we will never be able to understand it perfectly. Our limited understanding of the rules of nature allows us to make useful approximations, but no matter how accurate we try to become we will never achieve absolute certainty. I mean it may be possible to understand the fundamental rules (of the universe) and model it in some sort of computer, then it would just be a matter of finding ourselves in it. But who knows, I think the idea that people understand "God" absolutely perfectly, is inconsistent with human history, and our fundamental limitations. However the definition of what "God is" is an interesting concept, all religions have been arguing it throughout human history. I dont think its useless to consider the viewpoints that have developed over time, but of course everything has to be viewed through the lens of our limited perspective. Ie a good lie often has an element of truth.

I'm disappointed this unit is ending having narrowly and exclusively focused on Western tradition. I realize that's what most formal, historical philosophers of religion have concerned themselves with, but it's a laughably specific question: Does a personal, singular, male or agender, eternal, omni-god (whether all or only some of the omni-traits are accepted) exist?

There would be little reason to even be debating whether a deity with this particular cluster of traits existed if that belief were not already so widespread and influential.

What about pantheist, animist, Hindu and Buddhist concepts of divinity? Those are things I don't fully understand, and I would wager your audience in general has a significantly more shallow understanding of non-Western god-concepts than of Aquinas' god. Because these concepts are so much less widely understood, I think that makes them even more deserving of some examination. Surely, there must be philosophers that have wrestled with broader (or just non-Western) concepts of the divine, though maybe they're mostly more contemporary. It would be really cool if other concepts of god were covered in a later episode, at least.

Some people hear the words ‘Christian,’ or ‘God,’ and think of crazies like the Westboro Baptists or the Crusades or stuff like that. People like that, the kind of people who use the name of God like a knife, they aren’t the kind of people that really get the whole ‘Jesus,’ thing.

Christianity isn’t about damning people to hell, or doing lynchings in the backwoods. God doesn’t care if you’re black or white, gay or straight, God doesn’t care about what you are, or what you aren’t.

God loves you.

He ignores the best argument against Pascal's Wager; Itself. You assume that god X exists, but then you find out about the belief in god Y. Both beliefs are exclusive (the gods don't want you believing in other gods), and you can't reasonably assert which god exists and which god does not exist, so applying Pascal's Wager you are constantly switching between beliefs to try to satisfy both gods while failing to satisfy either of them, or rejecting Pascal's Wager and choosing to not believe in one of the gods.

With this video, I saw agnosticism and pragmatism feathering into each other. It would be pragmatic to believe in or at least allow the philosophical possibility of something, with innuendos similar to deism, while remaining firmly apart from theism or indeed any and all religions, extant or otherwise. This way, even as one rejects theistic belief systems and their often dubious moral codes, or even the concept of religious belief altogether, according to Pascal they should still remain on this potential allumma-whatsit's good side for not disbelieving the possibility altogether. A win-win, one might argue.

I was a little disappointed in the way this one handled pragmatism. There is a significant difference between something objectively working or subjectively working. The broad pragmatic argument for theism is a general argument for god, not constrained to any particular religion. To judge it objectively we have to look at the social benefits in a completely utilitarian sense. I kind of feel this blog bounced back and forth between subjective and objective arguments in a (possibly unconscious) biased way.
Oh well. Still love the series.

Hi crash course - about this series in general: just wondering why you picked these 'defenders of faith' in particular and not some others like Hazrat Ibn al Arabi or Mevlana Rumi, or even a back pocket version of the Tao te Ching? It seems like you're just setting us upon this cliche, western descent into the abyss. So many other things you could have mentioned like Essence and Attribute? Even Heidegger wrote about this...
anyway - the wager just works for the singular aspect of acknowledging the existence of a Creator, not for beliefs in general and certainly not for religions as wholes - and one of the biggest problems here is the confusion between the terms and realities of 'belief' and 'faith' and 'religion.' And before all that, something grossly misunderstood is that requiring 'faith in god' as opposed to 'knowledge of god' is implicitly atheistic. If there is an All-Powerful Creator and Sustainer of all existence, then shouldn't there be sufficient and readily accessible evidence? Of course! But what do you reckon to be the evidence and how do you determine if it is sufficient? What is the scale by which you determine the difference between obvious and skeptical? Do you think it reasonable to posit your tiny rational-faculty and limited material experience against even the vastness of our current material world let alone the endlessness of eternity and immateriality?
You cant just start off with a word like GOD, and go from there...then you get what we have here, people going back and forth and gaining nothing.
The real question is the question of Identity. First you have to understand something about the limits and capabilities of your own knowledge about yourself. Hey everyone, I'm a big fan and long time follower of Crash Course, primarily because I teach science classes at a Christian school. As a person of faith, I have never found Pascal's argument to be very compelling. The wager is primarily concerned with how your faith personally benefits you and less concerned with living according what is actually and factually true. As it's been stated in this series in the past, there are both good and bad reasons to accept a given premise as true, this would be a bad one. Kierkegaard, however, I've been a fan of since my days in college and in seminary. Granted he was kind of a weirdo in his personal life, but his concept of fideism challenges a primary theme in these videos, that being the primacy of human reason. While Kierkegaard valued reason as a philosopher, he understood that it has its limits because human beings are imperfect creatures and, as a result, our own thinking is faulty. So he suggests that in order to apprehend God through the eyes of faith we must commit the cardinal sin of modern humanism and take a leap away from reason and logic (at least at first) and into what he calls the "absurd".  Now, this doesn't mean we abandon reason and logic altogether, after all it is God who gave us our minds and expects us to use them to, say, to discuss and reason through things like morality, ethics, politics, etc. This initial surrendering of our reason isn't a sign of intellectual weakness or a lack of authenticity, but an acceptance that human reason isn't the ultimate justification for what is good, right, and true.

An "Anti-Pascal's Argument".

Pascal tacitly assumed that, if God exists, then he is a god that would behave in a way that people think that God ought to behave. However, what if God exists and does not behave the way the church says? Maybe if you believe in God, then you spend eternity in Hell when you die, and if you disbelieve in God, then you go to Heaven for all eternity when you die. While this sounds strange, it is every bit as possible as the "well behaved God" hypothesis of Pascal. In this case, using Pascal's original argument, you are better off not believing in God. If you play around with non testable hypotheses, then you can come to all sorts of conclusions.

One flaw that I like to point in Pascal's wager:
It doesn't count for situation where god happens to reward disbelief, and punish belief

Other is: belief in which god?

Pascal's Wager start's off with the wrong premise that God's existence is unknowable.
EVERYTHING is proof of the existence of a Creator as the first cause. Everything that begins to exist requires a cause. There must be an ALWAYS existing, uncaused first cause or nothing would exist. Since everything exists, there must have been an original source. Something cannot come from nothing per the laws of conservation of energy (energy and matter cannot be created or destroyed but only transformed.) Thus there must be an original Source everything came from (where the buck stops here.)

Don't say something you think is clever like "If everything came from something then where did God come from?" I said everything that BEGINS to exist must have a cause.

Holy Christmas. Dude, you are misinformed (and are, hence, a disseminator of misinformation). Here are just three things from the first five minutes:

1. You've defined pragmatism incorrectly. As a philosophical school, it isn't considered an alternative to finding truth; it is the belief that whatever works IS TRUE and is the principle means of locating it. Pragmatism isn't some nifty device people use, it's an entire epistemological theory.

2. William James' version of "pragmatism" was extremely unique and varied. And, while he did indeed promulgate a certain pragmatic theory of truth, he never considered himself a card-carrying member of the pragmatist school. Charles Sanders Peirce was the father, and chief apologist, of pragmatism.

3. Your understanding of Pascal's wager is the vulgar, populist one that treats it as a logical equation. Typically, those who interpret Pascal in this manner . . . HAVEN"T READ PASCAL. The point of the Wager was always to underscore how "monstrous" (to use Pascal's word) it is to treat the question of God's existence as if it were mere parlour talk. Pascal expends thousands of words on this matter in the lead up to the so-called "wager". As Pascal says right before laying it out, "We condemn those who live without thought of the ultimate end of life, who let themselves be guided by their own inclinations and their own pleasures without reflection and without concern, and, as if they could annihilate eternity by turning away their thought from it, think only of making themselves happy for the moment." If there's a "wager" at all, it was that the person who treats the matter of God as "trifling" (again, Pascal's word) is a person gambling with his life. His point, in short, is to not be flippant with dealing with the question of God but to consider it something that your entire life might be based on.

Fundamental flaw with the link between belief and reward: It is the assumption that God doesn't know the future and he is waiting to find out whether you will believe in him or not.

By definition, God is all knowing and all powerful. He knows whether you'll be a believer or not even before you exist. Thus he knows whether you will end up in Heaven or Hell even before you're born.

God knows the climax to the movie he created, scripted, directed and produced. Thus it doesn't make sense for him to punish ANYONE regardless of who you are and what you did.

I'm disappointed that you didn't bring up what is (in my opinion) the most crucial flaw in Pascal's wager: there is more than one possible God. Kinda disappointed that you didn't cover the fatal flaw in this argument, its basis in cultural chauvinism. Pascal rejects out of hand, or never even considers, that any other religion might be right. He presents the wager as a coin flip - believe in his god, or don't - when in reality it's a spin on the world's biggest roulette wheel, with thousands upon thousands of spots to place your bet.

But with the leap of faith in Indiana Jones, Indy does not have faith. He doesn't simply jump out into the abyss, he tests it by throwing sand forward to prove there is an invisible surface. This scene doesn't prove his faith, it cements his identity as a scientist: he makes a hypothesis (there's a way across), tests it (throws sand) , collects data (the sand is suspended in air), and forms a conclusion (there's an invisible surface). Now I know this is sort of jumping to conclusions, as having faith in god and being a scientist aren't mutually exclusive, but I always interpreted this scene as Indy rejecting blind faith and opting for the more reasonable approach, science.

Either faith is an arbitrary random choice one could just make on the fly or it is a reasoned conclusion that is inescapable to the believer.

The short answer is that Pascal's Wager completely fails.  For example, God is Allah (spoiler alert: God is not Allah, and in fact does not exist at all), then both the life-long Christian believer and the atheist go to Hell.  Also, if there is a God but he is testing us and hiding from us, and only rewards those who use their rational faculties to find that all of these human-created religions (Christianity, Islam, etc) are fake, then in fact, it would be only the atheist who would be rewarded by such a god, and not the Christian or Muslim.  Maybe God wants to see who will follow books that condone slavery and genocide (= the Bible and Qur'an, for a start), and then will punish those people, even though those people think they are going to Heaven.  In other words, there are so many situations - God not existing, God being the Christian god, God being a Hindu god, God being the Muslim God, God being a hidden god who rewards those who eschew all man-made (=all known) religions, etc, that there is no perfect bet.  In the end, evidence is required to believe, and that is where religious people run into problems.

One of the issues' I'm seeing with this series (and especially the comments!) is that the authors seem to be jumping from: Theistic argument for the existence of a god  directly to: Thus the Judeo-Christian god exists.  Then counter points are provided that demonstrate the argument in question is insufficient to prove the existence of a god with the attributes claimed by Jews/Christians&Muslims.  This is fair, in so much that this is the god on most westerners minds and the god most of the theistic philosophers had in mind also, but I don't think it quite fair to the arguments themselves. Pascal's wager or (even better) Aquinas' argument from infinite regress, are actually decent arguments for why one might be justified in believing a god exists, but that's all they do.  Nothing more.  A god. An unmoved mover.  An uncreated creator.  To demonstrate more, other arguments must be brought forth.  You can't go from Pascal's wager to, therefore everyone should become a Bible thumping evangelical Christian.  That just doesn't work and that's not what the arguments are for.

How can you move to existentialism without first considering Idealism and existentialism as a response to that. Of course to engage Idealism, you'd also have to encounter Hume (who has some great things to say in philosophy of religion via his essay "On Miracles"). Hume also leads to a great jumping off point to analytic philosophy, which, connected to philosophy of religion, culminated in the logical positivist movement (though that was an argument against the intelligibility of religious language more than anything). I recognize that you have to drawn the line somewhere, but my concern is that far too often people engage with existentialism as though they came out of no where with some radical new idea previously unaddressed (though this would doubtless make Sartre very happy). The fact is that in response to idealism, and in particular the idealism of Hegel, there was an initial negative response (via Nietzsche) and then a more positive response following Nietzsche in the twentieth century existentialists. The connect between Sartre, Camus and (yes really) even Woody Allen, on the one hand, to Kierkegaard on the other is their common response to idealism and analytic philosophy. Indeed they have little else in common considering the religious/spiritual tone of Kierkegaard compared to the "radical freedom" of atheism found in Sartre, Camus, Heidegger, and the like. I suppose we'll see, but this historical background is important and too often washed over. (Trey Medley, philosophy professor)

The biggest issue with Pascal's Wager is that it only holds if there is only one religion being considered. He doesn't account for the possible ramifications of believing in the wrong god. If we assume that all religions have a roughly equal chance of being true (the way Pascal renders God's existence and non-existence logically equal), then your odds of winding up in heaven are less than 1 in 4,000 with the remainder of possibilities largely being composed of brutal punishments. You have better odds of winning big by placing your life savings on a single number on a roulette table than winning this oft-overlooked aspect of Pascal's wager when you get right down to it.

The problem with Pascal's Wager isn't just that he's not considering other options - such as that other religions exist - but that it just can't cover any complex problem but just cover basic yes/no problems.

Which isn't always a bad thing. I've used this exact same argument when people say I shouldn't have given money to a beggar on the street because they could be pretending (which is actually happening in my city, the fuckers). So my two options are to give them money or not. I wager to give them money because at best I help someone who really needs it and at worst I've given a few dollars to an asshole. So in this very simple ethical problem Pascal's Wager is actually quite useful.

A lot of commenters have argued the many gods counter to Pascal's wager, but I prefer to counter with Pascal's mugging.  For those who aren't familiar with it and don't feel like just looking it up, here's a summary:  Pascal gets confronted by a mugger who forgot his weapon.  The mugger instead decides to ask for Pascal's wallet on the basis that the mugger will come back the next day with double whatever is in it.  When Pascal refuses, the mugger begins raising the promised amount to absurd levels.  The idea is that compared to the wallet, there must be some finite amount where the chance the mugger honors the deal is worth the risk, so at some point a believer of Pascal's wager would want to hand over the wallet. (note: this is actually an AI problem, but it's fun to bring up for philosophy anyway)

Surely if one were to approach belief in god pragmatically, as Pascal's Wager seems to do, then the most pragmatic thing would be to weigh belief in god against its real world benefits, and not against any supposed benefits in the afterlife. Because when you think about it, if God's existence can't be reasoned, as Pascal assumed, then neither can that of the afterlife.

That being said, it may be that we are going at belief in God all backwards. Most people tend to think of God as the starting point for the religious life. You believe in God, and from that belief derives all other beliefs and practices associated with the religion. That therefore creates the need to justify that initial belief. If you can't give a reasonable explanation for why you believe in God, then everything that is a consequence of that belief becomes irrational.

However, if you start to analyse belief in God as I described above, in terms of whether it has any utility in the real world, then you have to concede that there are preceding developments in the religious life that account for why people believe in God; something is making it beneficial, or even inclining a person to believe. So rather than being something that needs to be justified, God becomes the rationale for those things in the religious life that preceded it.

This approach is made even more pragmatic by the fact there are many religions that are either primarily orthopraxic (correction action), not theocentric, or both. How can belief in God be the reason people are religious if there are religions which are not theocentric?

So shouldn't the most pragmatic approach be to simply not start with belief in God, let alone trying to rationalize it?

His wager assumes only one religion - likely Christianity - and disregards all of the thousands of others we've created.

Since there are so many religions, all or most of which promising endless post-mortem torture to any who don't follow or believe in their tenets, then by sheer probability, we can all expect to have an unpleasant afterlife if even one of those religions is true, and there's no way to tell which one it might be. Pascal's reasoning did include a cost to false belief (and corresponding benefit to true disbelief), which he calls "the true." He says that human reason seeks knowledge, making us desire to believe true things and disbelieve false things, whereas human will seeks happiness. By assigning some finite intrinsic value to truth, Pascal is not properly a pragmatist, even though this is a pragmatic argument. Rather, he calculates that the reward of belief and risk of disbelief are infinite, whereas the risk of belief and reward of disbelief are finite, but still exist. That means that, according to his judgment, we ought to believe in God as long as there is any finite chance of his existence.

He does also say that the probability of existence and nonexistence are equal, because by his definition, God is completely ineffable. By definition, if we cannot know anything about something, the naive probability of it having any property is exactly fifty percent. That's how we assign probabilities to two mutually exclusive options with no other information to go on. Of course, by the same token, since we know nothing, we also have no more reason to believe God would reward our faith than punish it. So the argument really falls apart. It implicitly assumes there is rational reason to prefer a Biblical God to other possible Gods even though it includes as a premise that there can be no such reason. This cannot be easily fixed, because there are infinitely many possible contradictory versions of God who would demand different things, and since we cannot know God, we have no idea if anything we do or believe will have any effect, or which effect it will have, on our life or afterlife. So betting is indeed irrational.

Pascal's Wager is actually neither a bet for your eternal salvation nor against it because he ignores the third option. He gives the options that either God exists or he doesn't, but what about other possible gods besides the one he believed in? There are an infinite number of possible other gods, and among those are an infinite number of possible gods that would punish blind faith. In fact there are an infinite number of possible gods that want anything. The first option, that God exists, is actually part of the third option, simply that "A" god exists. As any one god is as likely as any other god Pascal's God is as likely as a god who wants the exact opposite and therefore Pascal's Wager is a wash. It does not follow from his reasoning that a belief in God has any impact on your well-being after death as a god that will punish something you do in life is equally as likely to exist as a god that will reward you for the same action.

Pascal's Wager falls down here: there have been an estimated ~1,000 religions in human history. Each one of their believers had just as much faith as people in surviving religions do. Most of them have their own heaven and their own hell and there will be many, many more to come in humanity's future. Christianity isn't special among the religions. Lots of people might like to think that it is, but it's just the most popular one right now. It will fall too, someday. The fact that taking the wager increases your chances of escaping eternal torture by .1% (not counting religions in the future) and the fact that doing so causes you to lose objectivity and reason (as well as a crap-ton of resources from building cathedrals) means that Pascal's wager is a bad wager to take.

My biggest problem with Pascal's Wager is that theism isn't simply binary. I mean, yes, broad strokes, you either believe there's a higher power or you don't. But there isn't just one God that you can choose to believe in. Humans have believed in a whole heavenly host of deities, from Ra to Zeus to Jehovah to Allah to the Flying Spaghetti Monster. If you choose to believe in the "wrong" one, then the "real" god is might punish you just as much, or possibly more, than if you were a non-believer. So if you're going to believe in a deity, you can't just go through the motions of whatever seems most convenient. You have to think long and hard about your beliefs.

Pascal's pragmatism fails because there are an innumerable alternative "faiths" which are contradictory to the traditional Judeo-Christian-Islamic god, none of which has any greater chance of being true than any other. Reducing it to a simple case, imagine two religions with exclusive deities, each of which promises eternal rewards for the faithful and eternal punishment for the unfaithful. The two religions are, a priori, equally likely to be true. In that case, choosing to believe in either religion entails the risk that you have chosen incorrectly. While this doesn't sound so bad if the odds are 50/50, it becomes substantially worse when there are thousands of alternatives. In the worst case, there is a "true" god or pantheon of gods who punish unbelievers and whose existence hasn't been posited yet.

On top of that, the universe doesn't seem to like unique things. If any god is real, the most likely scenario is that there is a large number of gods (perhaps an infinite number, if the universe is also infinite). This makes monotheistic religions less likely to be true than polytheistic religions.

One of the prime downfalls to Pascal's wager is the inherent assumption of the Judeo-Christian God in a binary sense.  It therefore lumps all "other" religions as "non-belief", but the assumptions made for non-belief do not fit the theologies of the other religions.  Clearly, most all religious 'faiths' promise essentially the same rewards, and each provide the same punishment for "non-belief", i.e. in their specific version of "God" or Gods.  Faced with such a choice, the odds are clearly against a person who chooses any one specific belief in the face of this many competing beliefs - however an honest desire to seek the truth and unwillingness to accept any "faith" in the lack of evidence of truth may in fact be seen as honourable and worthy of reward by almost any version of "God", making "non-belief" the pragmatic choice.

I really wish Begging The Question would have been addressed with Pascal, in that: The Wager alone cannot be 'an argument for existence' because it begs the question of existence for the aforementioned God/Being posited in the wager's question. For example, you cannot prove the existence of Zeus with the presupposition of Zeus's existence to begin with in a bet on His supposed ramifications 'a posteriori'. This is a non sequitur & fallacy.

After reading all of the comments I feel as though I don't even have to say something, but I will because I'm just like that. The palpable problem with Pascal's Wager is the assumption of limited options, either you believe and possibly go to heaven, or you disbelieve, eliminating any possible chance of paradise after death. This is the reason the wager falls flat, because you're already assuming that the possibilities are your God or no God at all. But as Christopher Hitchens put it rather humorously before, there could be a God and no afterlife, there could be many Gods and no afterlife, there could be a God with a sense of humor where good people went to hell and evil people went to paradise. There's an infinite number of possible outcomes, the wager only exists to people who have predetermined something already, that there can only be one God or no Gods at all.

But what if there's a god that will torture you if you believe in a god?
Since that's just as plausible (same amount of evidence, after all) as a god that will torture you if you don't believe in them, then pascal's wager cancels itself out.
(Edit: Alternatively, a god that tortures you if you believe in any god)

For every theoretical god with a certain will (it wants you to believe in it) there is a theoretical god with an opposite will (it doesn't want you to believe in it, or any others). So Pascal's wager always cancels itself out.


EDIT(x2): This argument is expanding Pascal's wager for any god. There's way more problems when one only applies it to the Christian god, like Pascal originally intended. (Thanks +Chris Seals)
So basically, I'm just stripping Pascal's wager down to the risk/reward argument. (Thanks +N. Wasinger)

Dear Hank and Literally Anyone Who Has Access to The Internet.

Since this is your last video on the Philosophy of Religion, I'll probably stop leaving such lengthy responses, since this is the one area of Philosophy I am knowledgeable in (to an extent), but I have some final thoughts, and I'll just leave them here in this monster of a YouTube comment.

I believe in God, and the New Testament because I believe that their message is the right one: Love your neighbor. I couldn't care less about Heaven, or Hell, I just want life on Earth to be the best it possibly could be, and if everyone cared for and appreciate everyone else, it would be. If some people need that motivator of eternal peace (or damnation), so be it, but I'm motivated by my faith in the human race to transcend violence and idiocy. That's why I have a problem (not a big one, or a serious one) with people who think that being dedicated to a religion and being dedicated to God's testaments are the same. Being dedicated to religion means dedicating yourself to people. Dedicating yourself to God's testaments is dedicating yourself to the betterment of mankind.

I genuinely believe some people just don't get the point. It's not believing in a God who may or may not exist, that doesn't really matter, what matters is listening to the wisdom he offers. Even if you don't believe in God, you can't say that if everyone loved everyone else, the world would be a better place.

P.S. I hope people don't misunderstand what I mean (and what the Bible means) when I mention "love". It's not our common understanding of love, it's basically just empathy and respect. Not alienating people for what they do or who they are.

Why oh why oh why do you choose to view philosophy through the lense of religion? Philosophy of religion is such a tiny subfield of the vast domain that is philosophy, and there are tons of metaphysical, ethical and epistemological questions to tackle that does not need to involve God: Are the entities in our scientific theories of the world real in the sense that they correspond with something mind-independent, or are they mere constructs that help us in making predictions, and model interactions, but not anything else? Are mental and physical states one and the same, or can something have mental properties over and above its physical properties? Can then the mental have causal powers over the physical? What is even causality? Is it rational to let go of our first-order beliefs in light of strong, but misleading, second-order evidence?
So many questions that illustrates how philosophy is still relevant in this science-centered world, and even provides tools to help us elucidate, analyse and critique our scientific theories. And yet we focus on the existence or non-existence of some non-descript deity whose character has only held relevance for philosophers. There might be some Divine Creator, Caring Father or Highest Judge, but the Perfect Being of St. Thomas Aquinas is simply too dull to worship.

I must say I find rebuttal Pascal's wager that focus on the practical costs of belief in God to be disappointing, because they do not question the merits of pragmatism itself, but, indeed, seem to play into it by assuming that pragmatism is «right» (rather than true - it doesn't make sense to say that pragmatism is true).

And that is actually my rebuttal - Pragmatism must be false because the notion that pragmatism is true can never not be vacuously so, while the notion that it is false is possible and meaningful.

Let us define two sorts of pragmatism :
Hard pragmatism : Truth does not exist independantly from practical use.
Soft pragmatism : Truth may or may not exist independaly from practical use, but we shouldn't care about independent truth anyway.

Note the interesting feature here that pragmatists, hard and soft, don't care about this distinction because it lacks practical use.


Let us understand this claim about pragmatism :

A : «Pragmatism is validated by truth.»

Either you go for a hard pragmatist understanding of truth, in which case claim A is vacuously true.
Or you go for a soft pragmatist understanding of truth, in which case claim A is meaningless.
Or you go for a non-pragmatist understanding of truth, in which case claim A must be false.

If our opinions on that thesis is that it can either be meaningless, vacuously true and meaningfully false, we should bet our opinion chips on meaningful falsehood because it's the only option that is enlightening about it.

Therefore, the notion that pragmatism is true entails, for pragmatists, reasons, that pragmatism must be false.
And that is actually a good pragmatical rebuttal of pragmatism, so pragmatism is absurd.

Kierkegaard was writing for a very specific audience; a Danish audience which was heavily Lutheran and greatly influenced by Georg Hegel. At the time, the Danish Church, in his view, was "wish-washy" with many people living as nominal Christians. Furthermore, because of Hegelianism, the trend was to view philosophy as the truest form (via reason) of the truth (or at least for obtaining it). Thus, since he disliked the state of affairs, he leaned in the opposite direction. When he says that faith is irrational, I think it should not be interpreted as him saying that faith and Christianity are completely separate from reason and justification but rather, they encompass reason and justification but ultimately extend beyond them. For Kierkegaard, faith is needed because there was no way for reason to figure out how an eternal being would step into time and space and be both fully human and fully divine.

"You can't tell anyone else that their belief is [...] dangerous." Umm, yes you can; just because they have faith because faith, doesn't mean their beliefs aren't also dangerous; just because they feel their belief is justified doesn't mean it can't also be dangerous.

Going back to Pascal's Wager, the most obvious flaw to me is that it isn't a dual question. It's not "should you believe in God?", it's "If I choose to believe in God, which one?" Even completely ignoring any non-Christian faiths, because Pascal was a European back in the day, so he probably didn't think about those, do you go protestant? Catholic? Orthodox? Calvinist? Only one of these can be right (if any of them even are), and if you bet on the wrong one, you get eternity in hell anyway.
Believing in God isn't like choose black against red on the roulette table; you have to choose a single number, and you don't even know if God's actual number is even on the table.

The most important argument against Pascal's Wager is one I have yet to see beaten. In fact, I think it's a perfect destruction of the idea. Basically, many people believe in many different gods. Pascal asks "Well, what if you're wrong? Better hedge your bets and believe in God." The answer to that is "No, what if YOU'RE wrong?" After all, people who believe in a single god are atheists to all other gods, many of whom promise eternal punishment for disbelief. Pascal's Wager isn't a good argument because there are plenty of gods to believe in and they can't all exist. It only makes sense if your worldview is the only one you consider, which is a very bad idea when you're trying to avoid eternal suffering and every huckster on every corner promises it to you if you don't do what they say.

Believing in any given god isn't going to make you more likely to avoid punishment, but it will likely take harmless enjoyment out of your life. If comfort and community mean more to you than any potential leisure lost, by all means enjoy your religion. But don't believe in it just because you're trying to avoid punishment, because that's a fallacious line of thinking.

This is not meant as an argument for theism, it is more one for an accepting agnosticism: For you could argue that the belief in “god” (here with a small “g”) is a different type of belief than the belief in the teapot; by being a metaphysical question. Take away the normative point in Kierkegaard’s philosophy and we will end at this point: We can’t “prove” god, so if you want to “believe” the only way is with faith alone. So hear me out: This only opens up for the accepting of believing in a metaphysical “god” NOT God. You might out of the believe in god find a way to argue for him being a special God but this can only be done by reasoning and (philosophical) argument, not by referring to scripture. In short: Since we by principle can’t prove the metaphysical question of god, we have to accept that some believe in “a god,” but that this belief (without proper argumentation) can’t justify a belief in a religion.

I enjoyed this one!! Using Russell's tea pot makes the excellent point that abandoning reason and evidence to justify belief on faith leaves us with no way to determine which faith based belief is correct. To me, the main problem with Pascal's Wager is that it only assumes one particular (Christian) God concept. So, in a way, it commits the false dichotomy fallacy. If the only choices in the whole universe were Christian God or no God, then the argument might be a good one. But there have been thousands of theistic belief systems, many of which contradict one another. If we accept logic at all, we must accept that they cannot all be correct. And faith doesn't help us distinguish which is true or false. If faith is enough justification for the Christian God, it's also enough justification for the Great Cosmic Purple Ape of Andromeda who created us and wishes to save us from the evil Milky Way and lead us to paradise. As a more general critique, I would also say the wager is built entirely on unfounded assumptions. Even if we accept that a God exists, why are we to assume that this God even has a reward and punishment system? Even if we accept that, why are we to assume that belief is a criterion for reward in God's system? For me, the wager stopped being compelling when I realized that. It became clear to me that I only found the wager compelling because I already bought into the premises of the Christian belief system. When I was a Christian, if a Pagan made the same argument to me for a whole pantheon of gods, I would have instantly seen the flaw in the logic. Yet Pascal's wager is just as valid for both belief systems. They are both compatible with Pascal's Wager, but they are not compatible with one another, because one of Christianity's central tenants is that there is only one God.

OK, there is one thing I've never been able to figure out about Pascal's Wager.

Why are the payouts the way they are? From a pragmatic point of view, I could believe God rewards everyone, regardless of their belief, or I could believe that God punishes believers and rewards unbelievers, or that God gives Trekkies pistachios and turns furries into sine waves.

Basically, why is Pascal's Wager the thing to focus on but not "Mohammed's Wager"?

The problem with Pascal's Wager isn't that one god might exist, but there are an infinite amount of possible gods that might exist.

God A might give eternal punishmemt and reward
God B might not care
God C might punish all
God D might punish all born on a Sunday

I could go on forever.

Simple matter. Pascal's wager is impractical because it is a bet on infinity. It isn't even pragmatic.
